00020 #if (OS_VERSION >= 251) && (OS_FLAG_EN > 0) && (OS_MAX_FLAGS > 0)
00021 /*
00022 *********************************************************************************************************
00023 *                                            LOCAL PROTOTYPES
00024 *********************************************************************************************************

00027 static  void     OS_FlagBlock(OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode, OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U wait_type, INT16U timeout);
00028 static  BOOLEAN  OS_FlagTaskRdy(OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode, OS_FLAGS flags_rdy);

00030 /*$PAGE*/
00031 /*
00032 *********************************************************************************************************
00033 *                              CHECK THE STATUS OF FLAGS IN AN EVENT FLAG GROUP
00034 *
00035 * Description: This function is called to check the status of a combination of bits to be set or cleared
00036 *              in an event flag group.  Your application can check for ANY bit to be set/cleared or ALL
00037 *              bits to be set/cleared.
00038 *
00039 *              This call does not block if the desired flags are not present.
00040 *
00041 * Arguments  : pgrp          is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00042 *
00043 *              flags         Is a bit pattern indicating which bit(s) (i.e. flags) you wish to check.
00044 *                            The bits you want are specified by setting the corresponding bits in
00045 *                            'flags'.  e.g. if your application wants to wait for bits 0 and 1 then
00046 *                            'flags' would contain 0x03.
00047 *
00048 *              wait_type     specifies whether you want ALL bits to be set/cleared or ANY of the bits
00049 *                            to be set/cleared.
00050 *                            You can specify the following argument:
00051 *
00052 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL   You will check ALL bits in 'flags' to be clear (0)
00053 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY   You will check ANY bit  in 'flags' to be clear (0)
00054 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL   You will check ALL bits in 'flags' to be set   (1)
00055 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY   You will check ANY bit  in 'flags' to be set   (1)
00056 *
00057 *                            NOTE: Add OS_FLAG_CONSUME if you want the event flag to be 'consumed' by
00058 *                                  the call.  Example, to wait for any flag in a group AND then clear
00059 *                                  the flags that are present, set 'wait_type' to:
00060 *
00061 *                                  OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY + OS_FLAG_CONSUME
00062 *
00063 *              err           is a pointer to an error code and can be:
00064 *                            OS_NO_ERR              No error
00065 *                            OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE      You are not pointing to an event flag group
00066 *                            OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE  You didn't specify a proper 'wait_type' argument.
00067 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP   You passed a NULL pointer instead of the event flag
00068 *                                                   group handle.
00069 *                            OS_FLAG_ERR_NOT_RDY    The desired flags you are waiting for are not
00070 *                                                   available.
00071 *
00072 * Returns    : The flags in the event flag group that made the task ready or, 0 if a timeout or an error 
00073 *              occurred.
00074 *
00075 * Called from: Task or ISR
00076 *
00077 * Note(s)    : 1) IMPORTANT, the behavior of this function has changed from PREVIOUS versions.  The
00078 *                 function NOW returns the flags that were ready INSTEAD of the current state of the 
00079 *                 event flags.
00080 *********************************************************************************************************
00081 */
00082 
00083 #if OS_FLAG_ACCEPT_EN > 0
00084 OS_FLAGS  OSFlagAccept (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U wait_type, INT8U *err)
00085 {
00086     OS_FLAGS      flags_rdy;
00087     BOOLEAN       consume;
00088 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                                /* Allocate storage for CPU status register */
00089     OS_CPU_SR     cpu_sr = 0;
00090 #endif    
00091 
00092 
00093 
00094 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00095     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                               /* Validate 'err'                           */
00096         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00097     }
00098     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {                        /* Validate 'pgrp'                          */
00099         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00100         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00101     }
00102 #endif
00103     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {          /* Validate event block type                */
00104         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00105         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00106     }
00107     if (wait_type & OS_FLAG_CONSUME) {                     /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00108         wait_type &= ~OS_FLAG_CONSUME;
00109         consume    = TRUE;
00110     } else {
00111         consume    = FALSE;
00112     }
00113 /*$PAGE*/
00114     *err = OS_NO_ERR;                                      /* Assume NO error until proven otherwise.  */
00115     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00116     switch (wait_type) {
00117         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL:                         /* See if all required flags are set        */
00118              flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;        /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00119              if (flags_rdy == flags) {                     /* Must match ALL the bits that we want     */
00120                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00121                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags_rdy;      /* Clear ONLY the flags that we wanted      */
00122                  }
00123              } else {
00124                  *err  = OS_FLAG_ERR_NOT_RDY;
00125              }
00126              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00127              break;
00128 
00129         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY:
00130              flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;        /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00131              if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {               /* See if any flag set                      */
00132                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00133                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags_rdy;      /* Clear ONLY the flags that we got         */
00134                  }
00135              } else {
00136                  *err  = OS_FLAG_ERR_NOT_RDY;
00137              }
00138              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00139              break;
00140 
00141 #if OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_EN > 0
00142         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL:                         /* See if all required flags are cleared    */
00143              flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;       /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00144              if (flags_rdy == flags) {                     /* Must match ALL the bits that we want     */
00145                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00146                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags |= flags_rdy;       /* Set ONLY the flags that we wanted        */
00147                  }
00148              } else {
00149                  *err  = OS_FLAG_ERR_NOT_RDY;
00150              }
00151              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00152              break;
00153 
00154         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY:
00155              flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;       /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00156              if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {               /* See if any flag cleared                  */
00157                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00158                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags |= flags_rdy;       /* Set ONLY the flags that we got           */
00159                  }
00160              } else {
00161                  *err  = OS_FLAG_ERR_NOT_RDY;
00162              }
00163              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00164              break;
00165 #endif
00166 
00167         default:
00168              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00169              flags_rdy = (OS_FLAGS)0;
00170              *err      = OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE;
00171              break;
00172     }
00173     return (flags_rdy);
00174 }
00175 #endif
00176 
00177 /*$PAGE*/
00178 /*
00179 *********************************************************************************************************
00180 *                                           CREATE AN EVENT FLAG
00181 *
00182 * Description: This function is called to create an event flag group.
00183 *
00184 * Arguments  : flags         Contains the initial value to store in the event flag group.
00185 *
00186 *              err           is a pointer to an error code which will be returned to your application:
00187 *                               OS_NO_ERR                if the call was successful.
00188 *                               OS_ERR_CREATE_ISR        if you attempted to create an Event Flag from an
00189 *                                                        ISR.
00190 *                               OS_FLAG_GRP_DEPLETED     if there are no more event flag groups
00191 *
00192 * Returns    : A pointer to an event flag group or a NULL pointer if no more groups are available.
00193 *
00194 * Called from: Task ONLY
00195 *********************************************************************************************************
00196 */
00197 
00198 OS_FLAG_GRP  *OSFlagCreate (OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U *err)
00199 {
00200     OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp;
00201 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                         /* Allocate storage for CPU status register        */
00202     OS_CPU_SR    cpu_sr = 0;
00203 #endif    
00204 
00205 
00206 
00207 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00208     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                        /* Validate 'err'                                  */
00209         return ((OS_FLAG_GRP *)0);
00210     }
00211 #endif    
00212     if (OSIntNesting > 0) {                         /* See if called from ISR ...                      */
00213         *err = OS_ERR_CREATE_ISR;                   /* ... can't CREATE from an ISR                    */
00214         return ((OS_FLAG_GRP *)0);
00215     }
00216     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00217     pgrp = OSFlagFreeList;                          /* Get next free event flag                        */
00218     if (pgrp != (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {                 /* See if we have event flag groups available      */
00219                                                     /* Adjust free list                                */
00220         OSFlagFreeList       = (OS_FLAG_GRP *)OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagWaitList;
00221         pgrp->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG;  /* Set to event flag group type                    */
00222         pgrp->OSFlagFlags    = flags;               /* Set to desired initial value                    */
00223         pgrp->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)0;           /* Clear list of tasks waiting on flags            */
00224 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
00225         pgrp->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';
00226         pgrp->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
00227 #endif
00228         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00229         *err                 = OS_NO_ERR;
00230     } else {
00231         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00232         *err                 = OS_FLAG_GRP_DEPLETED;
00233     }
00234     return (pgrp);                                  /* Return pointer to event flag group              */
00235 }
00236 
00237 /*$PAGE*/
00238 /*
00239 *********************************************************************************************************
00240 *                                     DELETE AN EVENT FLAG GROUP
00241 *
00242 * Description: This function deletes an event flag group and readies all tasks pending on the event flag
00243 *              group.
00244 *
00245 * Arguments  : pgrp          is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00246 *
00247 *              opt           determines delete options as follows:
00248 *                            opt == OS_DEL_NO_PEND   Deletes the event flag group ONLY if no task pending
00249 *                            opt == OS_DEL_ALWAYS    Deletes the event flag group even if tasks are
00250 *                                                    waiting.  In this case, all the tasks pending will be
00251 *                                                    readied.
00252 *
00253 *              err           is a pointer to an error code that can contain one of the following values:
00254 *                            OS_NO_ERR               The call was successful and the event flag group was
00255 *                                                    deleted
00256 *                            OS_ERR_DEL_ISR          If you attempted to delete the event flag group from
00257 *                                                    an ISR
00258 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP    If 'pgrp' is a NULL pointer.
00259 *                            OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE       If you didn't pass a pointer to an event flag group
00260 *                            OS_ERR_INVALID_OPT      An invalid option was specified
00261 *                            OS_ERR_TASK_WAITING     One or more tasks were waiting on the event flag
00262 *                                                    group.
00263 *
00264 * Returns    : pgrp          upon error
00265 *              (OS_EVENT *)0 if the event flag group was successfully deleted.
00266 *
00267 * Note(s)    : 1) This function must be used with care.  Tasks that would normally expect the presence of
00268 *                 the event flag group MUST check the return code of OSFlagAccept() and OSFlagPend().
00269 *              2) This call can potentially disable interrupts for a long time.  The interrupt disable
00270 *                 time is directly proportional to the number of tasks waiting on the event flag group.
00271 *********************************************************************************************************
00272 */
00273 
00274 #if OS_FLAG_DEL_EN > 0
00275 OS_FLAG_GRP  *OSFlagDel (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, INT8U opt, INT8U *err)
00276 {
00277     BOOLEAN       tasks_waiting;
00278     OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode;
00279 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                                /* Allocate storage for CPU status register */
00280     OS_CPU_SR     cpu_sr = 0;
00281 #endif    
00282 
00283 
00284 
00285 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00286     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                               /* Validate 'err'                           */
00287         return (pgrp);
00288     }
00289     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {                        /* Validate 'pgrp'                          */
00290         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00291         return (pgrp);
00292     }
00293 #endif
00294     if (OSIntNesting > 0) {                                /* See if called from ISR ...               */
00295         *err = OS_ERR_DEL_ISR;                             /* ... can't DELETE from an ISR             */
00296         return (pgrp);
00297     }
00298     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {          /* Validate event group type                */
00299         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00300         return (pgrp);
00301     }
00302     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00303     if (pgrp->OSFlagWaitList != (void *)0) {               /* See if any tasks waiting on event flags  */
00304         tasks_waiting = TRUE;                              /* Yes                                      */
00305     } else {
00306         tasks_waiting = FALSE;                             /* No                                       */
00307     }
00308     switch (opt) {
00309         case OS_DEL_NO_PEND:                               /* Delete group if no task waiting          */
00310              if (tasks_waiting == FALSE) {
00311 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
00312                  pgrp->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';               /* Unknown name                             */
00313                  pgrp->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
00314 #endif
00315                  pgrp->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_UNUSED;
00316                  pgrp->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)OSFlagFreeList; /* Return group to free list           */
00317                  pgrp->OSFlagFlags    = (OS_FLAGS)0;
00318                  OSFlagFreeList       = pgrp;
00319                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00320                  *err                 = OS_NO_ERR;
00321                  return ((OS_FLAG_GRP *)0);                /* Event Flag Group has been deleted        */
00322              } else {
00323                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00324                  *err                 = OS_ERR_TASK_WAITING;
00325                  return (pgrp);
00326              }
00327 
00328         case OS_DEL_ALWAYS:                                /* Always delete the event flag group       */
00329              pnode = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pgrp->OSFlagWaitList;
00330              while (pnode != (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0) {          /* Ready ALL tasks waiting for flags        */
00331                  (void)OS_FlagTaskRdy(pnode, (OS_FLAGS)0);
00332                  pnode = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pnode->OSFlagNodeNext;
00333              }
00334 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
00335              pgrp->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';                   /* Unknown name                             */
00336              pgrp->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
00337 #endif
00338              pgrp->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_UNUSED;
00339              pgrp->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)OSFlagFreeList;/* Return group to free list                */
00340              pgrp->OSFlagFlags    = (OS_FLAGS)0;
00341              OSFlagFreeList       = pgrp;
00342              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00343              if (tasks_waiting == TRUE) {                  /* Reschedule only if task(s) were waiting  */
00344                  OS_Sched();                               /* Find highest priority task ready to run  */
00345              }
00346              *err = OS_NO_ERR;
00347              return ((OS_FLAG_GRP *)0);                    /* Event Flag Group has been deleted        */
00348 
00349         default:
00350              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00351              *err = OS_ERR_INVALID_OPT;
00352              return (pgrp);
00353     }
00354 }
00355 #endif
00356 /*$PAGE*/
00357 /*
00358 *********************************************************************************************************
00359 *                                 GET THE NAME OF AN EVENT FLAG GROUP
00360 *
00361 * Description: This function is used to obtain the name assigned to an event flag group
00362 *
00363 * Arguments  : pgrp      is a pointer to the event flag group.
00364 *
00365 *              pname     is a pointer to an ASCII string that will receive the name of the event flag
00366 *                        group.  The string must be able to hold at least OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE characters.
00367 *
00368 *              err       is a pointer to an error code that can contain one of the following values:
00369 *
00370 *                        OS_NO_ERR                  if the requested task is resumed
00371 *                        OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE          if 'pevent' is not pointing to an event flag group
00372 *                        OS_ERR_PNAME_NULL          You passed a NULL pointer for 'pname'
00373 *                        OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP       if you passed a NULL pointer for 'pgrp'
00374 *
00375 * Returns    : The length of the string or 0 if the 'pgrp' is a NULL pointer.
00376 *********************************************************************************************************
00377 */
00378 
00379 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
00380 INT8U  OSFlagNameGet (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, char *pname, INT8U *err)
00381 {
00382     INT8U      len;
00383 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                      /* Allocate storage for CPU status register           */
00384     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00385 #endif    
00386 
00387 
00388 
00389     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00390 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00391     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                     /* Validate 'err'                                     */
00392         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00393         return (0);
00394     }
00395     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {              /* Is 'pgrp' a NULL pointer?                          */
00396         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                      /* Yes                                                */
00397         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00398         return (0);
00399     }
00400     if (pname == (char *)0) {                    /* Is 'pname' a NULL pointer?                         */
00401         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                      /* Yes                                                */
00402         *err = OS_ERR_PNAME_NULL;
00403         return (0);
00404     }
00405 #endif
00406     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {
00407         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00408         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00409         return (0);
00410     }
00411     len  = OS_StrCopy(pname, pgrp->OSFlagName);  /* Copy name from OS_FLAG_GRP                         */
00412     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00413     *err = OS_NO_ERR;
00414     return (len);
00415 }
00416 #endif
00417 
00418 /*$PAGE*/
00419 /*
00420 *********************************************************************************************************
00421 *                                 ASSIGN A NAME TO AN EVENT FLAG GROUP
00422 *
00423 * Description: This function assigns a name to an event flag group.
00424 *
00425 * Arguments  : pgrp      is a pointer to the event flag group. 
00426 *
00427 *              pname     is a pointer to an ASCII string that will be used as the name of the event flag
00428 *                        group.  The string must be able to hold at least OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE characters.
00429 *
00430 *              err       is a pointer to an error code that can contain one of the following values:
00431 *
00432 *                        OS_NO_ERR                  if the requested task is resumed
00433 *                        OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE          if 'pevent' is not pointing to an event flag group
00434 *                        OS_ERR_PNAME_NULL          You passed a NULL pointer for 'pname'
00435 *                        OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP       if you passed a NULL pointer for 'pgrp'
00436 *
00437 * Returns    : None
00438 *********************************************************************************************************
00439 */
00440 
00441 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
00442 void  OSFlagNameSet (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, char *pname, INT8U *err)
00443 {
00444     INT8U      len;
00445 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                      /* Allocate storage for CPU status register           */
00446     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00447 #endif    
00448 
00449 
00450 
00451     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00452 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00453     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                     /* Validate 'err'                                     */
00454         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00455         return;
00456     }
00457     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {              /* Is 'pgrp' a NULL pointer?                          */
00458         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                      /* Yes                                                */
00459         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00460         return;
00461     }
00462     if (pname == (char *)0) {                    /* Is 'pname' a NULL pointer?                         */
00463         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                      /* Yes                                                */
00464         *err = OS_ERR_PNAME_NULL;
00465         return;
00466     }
00467 #endif
00468     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {
00469         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00470         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00471         return;
00472     }
00473     len = OS_StrLen(pname);                      /* Can we fit the string in the storage area?         */
00474     if (len > (OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE - 1)) {         /* No                                                 */
00475         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00476         *err = OS_ERR_FLAG_NAME_TOO_LONG;
00477         return;
00478     } 
00479     (void)OS_StrCopy(pgrp->OSFlagName, pname);   /* Yes, copy name from OS_FLAG_GRP                    */
00480     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00481     *err = OS_NO_ERR;
00482     return;
00483 }
00484 #endif
00485 
00486 /*$PAGE*/
00487 /*
00488 *********************************************************************************************************
00489 *                                        WAIT ON AN EVENT FLAG GROUP
00490 *
00491 * Description: This function is called to wait for a combination of bits to be set in an event flag
00492 *              group.  Your application can wait for ANY bit to be set or ALL bits to be set.
00493 *
00494 * Arguments  : pgrp          is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00495 *
00496 *              flags         Is a bit pattern indicating which bit(s) (i.e. flags) you wish to wait for.
00497 *                            The bits you want are specified by setting the corresponding bits in
00498 *                            'flags'.  e.g. if your application wants to wait for bits 0 and 1 then
00499 *                            'flags' would contain 0x03.
00500 *
00501 *              wait_type     specifies whether you want ALL bits to be set or ANY of the bits to be set.
00502 *                            You can specify the following argument:
00503 *
00504 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL   You will wait for ALL bits in 'mask' to be clear (0)
00505 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL   You will wait for ALL bits in 'mask' to be set   (1)
00506 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY   You will wait for ANY bit  in 'mask' to be clear (0)
00507 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY   You will wait for ANY bit  in 'mask' to be set   (1)
00508 *
00509 *                            NOTE: Add OS_FLAG_CONSUME if you want the event flag to be 'consumed' by
00510 *                                  the call.  Example, to wait for any flag in a group AND then clear
00511 *                                  the flags that are present, set 'wait_type' to:
00512 *
00513 *                                  OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY + OS_FLAG_CONSUME
00514 *
00515 *              timeout       is an optional timeout (in clock ticks) that your task will wait for the
00516 *                            desired bit combination.  If you specify 0, however, your task will wait
00517 *                            forever at the specified event flag group or, until a message arrives.
00518 *
00519 *              err           is a pointer to an error code and can be:
00520 *                            OS_NO_ERR              The desired bits have been set within the specified
00521 *                                                   'timeout'.
00522 *                            OS_ERR_PEND_ISR        If you tried to PEND from an ISR
00523 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP   If 'pgrp' is a NULL pointer.
00524 *                            OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE      You are not pointing to an event flag group
00525 *                            OS_TIMEOUT             The bit(s) have not been set in the specified
00526 *                                                   'timeout'.
00527 *                            OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE  You didn't specify a proper 'wait_type' argument.
00528 *
00529 * Returns    : The flags in the event flag group that made the task ready or, 0 if a timeout or an error 
00530 *              occurred.
00531 *
00532 * Called from: Task ONLY
00533 *
00534 * Note(s)    : 1) IMPORTANT, the behavior of this function has changed from PREVIOUS versions.  The
00535 *                 function NOW returns the flags that were ready INSTEAD of the current state of the 
00536 *                 event flags.
00537 *********************************************************************************************************
00538 */
00539 
00540 OS_FLAGS  OSFlagPend (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U wait_type, INT16U timeout, INT8U *err)
00541 {
00542     OS_FLAG_NODE  node;
00543     OS_FLAGS      flags_rdy;
00544     BOOLEAN       consume;
00545 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                                /* Allocate storage for CPU status register */
00546     OS_CPU_SR     cpu_sr = 0;
00547 #endif    
00548 
00549 
00550 
00551 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00552     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                               /* Validate 'err'                           */
00553         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00554     }
00555     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {                        /* Validate 'pgrp'                          */
00556         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00557         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00558     }
00559 #endif
00560     if (OSIntNesting > 0) {                                /* See if called from ISR ...               */
00561         *err = OS_ERR_PEND_ISR;                            /* ... can't PEND from an ISR               */
00562         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00563     }
00564     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {          /* Validate event block type                */
00565         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00566         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00567     }
00568     if (wait_type & OS_FLAG_CONSUME) {                     /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00569         wait_type &= ~OS_FLAG_CONSUME;
00570         consume    = TRUE;
00571     } else {
00572         consume    = FALSE;
00573     }
00574 /*$PAGE*/
00575     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00576     switch (wait_type) {
00577         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL:                         /* See if all required flags are set        */
00578              flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;        /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00579              if (flags_rdy == flags) {                     /* Must match ALL the bits that we want     */
00580                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00581                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags_rdy;      /* Clear ONLY the flags that we wanted      */
00582                  }
00583                  OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy = flags_rdy;      /* Save flags that were ready               */
00584                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                       /* Yes, condition met, return to caller     */
00585                  *err                    = OS_NO_ERR;
00586                  return (flags_rdy);
00587              } else {                                      /* Block task until events occur or timeout */
00588                  OS_FlagBlock(pgrp, &node, flags, wait_type, timeout);
00589                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00590              }
00591              break;
00592 
00593         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY:
00594              flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;        /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00595              if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {               /* See if any flag set                      */
00596                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00597                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags_rdy;      /* Clear ONLY the flags that we got         */
00598                  }
00599                  OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy = flags_rdy;      /* Save flags that were ready               */
00600                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                       /* Yes, condition met, return to caller     */
00601                  *err                    = OS_NO_ERR;
00602                  return (flags_rdy);
00603              } else {                                      /* Block task until events occur or timeout */
00604                  OS_FlagBlock(pgrp, &node, flags, wait_type, timeout);
00605                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00606              }
00607              break;
00608 
00609 #if OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_EN > 0
00610         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL:                         /* See if all required flags are cleared    */
00611              flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;       /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00612              if (flags_rdy == flags) {                     /* Must match ALL the bits that we want     */
00613                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00614                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags |= flags_rdy;       /* Set ONLY the flags that we wanted        */
00615                  }
00616                  OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy = flags_rdy;      /* Save flags that were ready               */
00617                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                       /* Yes, condition met, return to caller     */
00618                  *err                    = OS_NO_ERR;
00619                  return (flags_rdy);
00620              } else {                                      /* Block task until events occur or timeout */
00621                  OS_FlagBlock(pgrp, &node, flags, wait_type, timeout);
00622                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00623              }
00624              break;
00625 
00626         case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY:
00627              flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & flags;       /* Extract only the bits we want            */
00628              if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {               /* See if any flag cleared                  */
00629                  if (consume == TRUE) {                    /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00630                      pgrp->OSFlagFlags |= flags_rdy;       /* Set ONLY the flags that we got           */
00631                  }
00632                  OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy = flags_rdy;      /* Save flags that were ready               */
00633                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                       /* Yes, condition met, return to caller     */
00634                  *err                    = OS_NO_ERR;
00635                  return (flags_rdy);
00636              } else {                                      /* Block task until events occur or timeout */
00637                  OS_FlagBlock(pgrp, &node, flags, wait_type, timeout);
00638                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00639              }
00640              break;
00641 #endif
00642 
00643         default:
00644              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00645              flags_rdy = (OS_FLAGS)0;
00646              *err      = OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE;
00647              return (flags_rdy);
00648     }
00649     OS_Sched();                                            /* Find next HPT ready to run               */
00650     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00651     if (OSTCBCur->OSTCBPendTO == TRUE) {                   /* Have we timed-out?                       */
00652         OSTCBCur->OSTCBPendTO = FALSE;
00653         OS_FlagUnlink(&node);
00654         OSTCBCur->OSTCBStat   = OS_STAT_RDY;               /* Yes, make task ready-to-run              */
00655         OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00656         flags_rdy             = (OS_FLAGS)0;
00657         *err                  = OS_TIMEOUT;                /* Indicate that we timed-out waiting       */
00658         return (flags_rdy);
00659     } 
00660     flags_rdy = OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy;
00661     if (consume == TRUE) {                                 /* See if we need to consume the flags      */
00662         switch (wait_type) {
00663             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL:
00664             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY:                     /* Clear ONLY the flags we got              */
00665                  pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags_rdy;
00666                  break;
00667 
00668 #if OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_EN > 0
00669             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL:
00670             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY:                     /* Set   ONLY the flags we got              */
00671                  pgrp->OSFlagFlags |=  flags_rdy;
00672                  break;
00673 #endif
00674             default:
00675                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00676                  *err = OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE;
00677                  return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00678         }
00679     }
00680     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00681     *err = OS_NO_ERR;                                      /* Event(s) must have occurred              */
00682     return (flags_rdy);
00683 }
00684 /*$PAGE*/
00685 /*
00686 *********************************************************************************************************
00687 *                               GET FLAGS WHO CAUSED TASK TO BECOME READY
00688 *
00689 * Description: This function is called to obtain the flags that caused the task to become ready to run.
00690 *              In other words, this function allows you to tell "Who done it!".
00691 *
00692 * Arguments  : None
00693 *
00694 * Returns    : The flags that caused the task to be ready.
00695 *
00696 * Called from: Task ONLY
00697 *********************************************************************************************************
00698 */
00699 
00700 OS_FLAGS  OSFlagPendGetFlagsRdy (void)
00701 {
00702     OS_FLAGS      flags;
00703 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                                /* Allocate storage for CPU status register */
00704     OS_CPU_SR     cpu_sr = 0;
00705 #endif    
00706 
00707 
00708 
00709     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00710     flags = OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagsRdy;
00711     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00712     return (flags);
00713 }
00714 
00715 /*$PAGE*/
00716 /*
00717 *********************************************************************************************************
00718 *                                         POST EVENT FLAG BIT(S)
00719 *
00720 * Description: This function is called to set or clear some bits in an event flag group.  The bits to
00721 *              set or clear are specified by a 'bit mask'.
00722 *
00723 * Arguments  : pgrp          is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00724 *
00725 *              flags         If 'opt' (see below) is OS_FLAG_SET, each bit that is set in 'flags' will
00726 *                            set the corresponding bit in the event flag group.  e.g. to set bits 0, 4
00727 *                            and 5 you would set 'flags' to:
00728 *
00729 *                                0x31     (note, bit 0 is least significant bit)
00730 *
00731 *                            If 'opt' (see below) is OS_FLAG_CLR, each bit that is set in 'flags' will
00732 *                            CLEAR the corresponding bit in the event flag group.  e.g. to clear bits 0,
00733 *                            4 and 5 you would specify 'flags' as:
00734 *
00735 *                                0x31     (note, bit 0 is least significant bit)
00736 *
00737 *              opt           indicates whether the flags will be:
00738 *                                set     (OS_FLAG_SET) or
00739 *                                cleared (OS_FLAG_CLR)
00740 *
00741 *              err           is a pointer to an error code and can be:
00742 *                            OS_NO_ERR              The call was successfull
00743 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP   You passed a NULL pointer
00744 *                            OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE      You are not pointing to an event flag group
00745 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_OPT    You specified an invalid option
00746 *
00747 * Returns    : the new value of the event flags bits that are still set.
00748 *
00749 * Called From: Task or ISR
00750 *
00751 * WARNING(s) : 1) The execution time of this function depends on the number of tasks waiting on the event
00752 *                 flag group.
00753 *              2) The amount of time interrupts are DISABLED depends on the number of tasks waiting on
00754 *                 the event flag group.
00755 *********************************************************************************************************
00756 */
00757 OS_FLAGS  OSFlagPost (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U opt, INT8U *err)
00758 {
00759     OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode;
00760     BOOLEAN       sched;
00761     OS_FLAGS      flags_cur;
00762     OS_FLAGS      flags_rdy;
00763     BOOLEAN       rdy;
00764 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                          /* Allocate storage for CPU status register       */
00765     OS_CPU_SR     cpu_sr = 0;
00766 #endif    
00767 
00768 
00769 
00770 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00771     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                         /* Validate 'err'                                 */
00772         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00773     }
00774     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {                  /* Validate 'pgrp'                                */
00775         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00776         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00777     }
00778 #endif
00779     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) {    /* Make sure we are pointing to an event flag grp */
00780         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00781         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00782     }
00783 /*$PAGE*/
00784     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00785     switch (opt) {
00786         case OS_FLAG_CLR:
00787              pgrp->OSFlagFlags &= ~flags;            /* Clear the flags specified in the group         */
00788              break;
00789 
00790         case OS_FLAG_SET:
00791              pgrp->OSFlagFlags |=  flags;            /* Set   the flags specified in the group         */
00792              break;
00793 
00794         default:
00795              OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();                     /* INVALID option                                 */
00796              *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_OPT;
00797              return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00798     }
00799     sched = FALSE;                                   /* Indicate that we don't need rescheduling       */
00800     pnode = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pgrp->OSFlagWaitList;
00801     while (pnode != (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0) {             /* Go through all tasks waiting on event flag(s)  */
00802         switch (pnode->OSFlagNodeWaitType) {
00803             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL:               /* See if all req. flags are set for current node */
00804                  flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags;
00805                  if (flags_rdy == pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags) {
00806                      rdy = OS_FlagTaskRdy(pnode, flags_rdy);  /* Make task RTR, event(s) Rx'd          */
00807                      if (rdy == TRUE) {                     
00808                          sched = TRUE;                        /* When done we will reschedule          */
00809                      }
00810                  }
00811                  break;
00812 
00813             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY:               /* See if any flag set                            */
00814                  flags_rdy = pgrp->OSFlagFlags & pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags;
00815                  if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {
00816                      rdy = OS_FlagTaskRdy(pnode, flags_rdy);  /* Make task RTR, event(s) Rx'd          */
00817                      if (rdy == TRUE) {                      
00818                          sched = TRUE;                        /* When done we will reschedule          */
00819                      }
00820                  }
00821                  break;
00822 
00823 #if OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_EN > 0
00824             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL:               /* See if all req. flags are set for current node */
00825                  flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags;
00826                  if (flags_rdy == pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags) {
00827                      rdy = OS_FlagTaskRdy(pnode, flags_rdy);  /* Make task RTR, event(s) Rx'd          */
00828                      if (rdy == TRUE) {                       
00829                          sched = TRUE;                        /* When done we will reschedule          */
00830                      }
00831                  }
00832                  break;
00833 
00834             case OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY:               /* See if any flag set                            */
00835                  flags_rdy = ~pgrp->OSFlagFlags & pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags;
00836                  if (flags_rdy != (OS_FLAGS)0) {
00837                      rdy = OS_FlagTaskRdy(pnode, flags_rdy);  /* Make task RTR, event(s) Rx'd          */
00838                      if (rdy == TRUE) {                       
00839                          sched = TRUE;                        /* When done we will reschedule          */
00840                      }
00841                  }
00842                  break;
00843 #endif
00844             default:
00845                  OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00846                  *err = OS_FLAG_ERR_WAIT_TYPE;
00847                  return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00848         }
00849         pnode = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pnode->OSFlagNodeNext; /* Point to next task waiting for event flag(s) */
00850     }
00851     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00852     if (sched == TRUE) {
00853         OS_Sched();
00854     }
00855     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00856     flags_cur = pgrp->OSFlagFlags;
00857     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00858     *err      = OS_NO_ERR;
00859     return (flags_cur);
00860 }
00861 /*$PAGE*/
00862 /*
00863 *********************************************************************************************************
00864 *                                           QUERY EVENT FLAG
00865 *
00866 * Description: This function is used to check the value of the event flag group.
00867 *
00868 * Arguments  : pgrp         is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00869 *
00870 *              err           is a pointer to an error code returned to the called:
00871 *                            OS_NO_ERR              The call was successfull
00872 *                            OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP   You passed a NULL pointer
00873 *                            OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE      You are not pointing to an event flag group
00874 *
00875 * Returns    : The current value of the event flag group.
00876 *
00877 * Called From: Task or ISR
00878 *********************************************************************************************************
00879 */
00880 
00881 #if OS_FLAG_QUERY_EN > 0
00882 OS_FLAGS  OSFlagQuery (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, INT8U *err)
00883 {
00884     OS_FLAGS   flags;
00885 #if OS_CRITICAL_METHOD == 3                       /* Allocate storage for CPU status register          */
00886     OS_CPU_SR  cpu_sr = 0;
00887 #endif    
00888 
00889 
00890 
00891 #if OS_ARG_CHK_EN > 0
00892     if (err == (INT8U *)0) {                      /* Validate 'err'                                    */
00893         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00894     }
00895     if (pgrp == (OS_FLAG_GRP *)0) {               /* Validate 'pgrp'                                   */
00896         *err = OS_FLAG_INVALID_PGRP;
00897         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00898     }
00899 #endif
00900     if (pgrp->OSFlagType != OS_EVENT_TYPE_FLAG) { /* Validate event block type                         */
00901         *err = OS_ERR_EVENT_TYPE;
00902         return ((OS_FLAGS)0);
00903     }
00904     OS_ENTER_CRITICAL();
00905     flags = pgrp->OSFlagFlags;
00906     OS_EXIT_CRITICAL();
00907     *err = OS_NO_ERR;
00908     return (flags);                               /* Return the current value of the event flags       */
00909 }
00910 #endif
00911 
00912 /*$PAGE*/
00913 /*
00914 *********************************************************************************************************
00915 *                         SUSPEND TASK UNTIL EVENT FLAG(s) RECEIVED OR TIMEOUT OCCURS
00916 *
00917 * Description: This function is internal to uC/OS-II and is used to put a task to sleep until the desired
00918 *              event flag bit(s) are set.
00919 *
00920 * Arguments  : pgrp          is a pointer to the desired event flag group.
00921 *
00922 *              pnode         is a pointer to a structure which contains data about the task waiting for
00923 *                            event flag bit(s) to be set.
00924 *
00925 *              flags         Is a bit pattern indicating which bit(s) (i.e. flags) you wish to check.
00926 *                            The bits you want are specified by setting the corresponding bits in
00927 *                            'flags'.  e.g. if your application wants to wait for bits 0 and 1 then
00928 *                            'flags' would contain 0x03.
00929 *
00930 *              wait_type     specifies whether you want ALL bits to be set/cleared or ANY of the bits
00931 *                            to be set/cleared.
00932 *                            You can specify the following argument:
00933 *
00934 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ALL   You will check ALL bits in 'mask' to be clear (0)
00935 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_CLR_ANY   You will check ANY bit  in 'mask' to be clear (0)
00936 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ALL   You will check ALL bits in 'mask' to be set   (1)
00937 *                            OS_FLAG_WAIT_SET_ANY   You will check ANY bit  in 'mask' to be set   (1)
00938 *
00939 *              timeout       is the desired amount of time that the task will wait for the event flag
00940 *                            bit(s) to be set.
00941 *
00942 * Returns    : none
00943 *
00944 * Called by  : OSFlagPend()  OS_FLAG.C
00945 *
00946 * Note(s)    : This function is INTERNAL to uC/OS-II and your application should not call it.
00947 *********************************************************************************************************
00948 */
00949 
00950 static  void  OS_FlagBlock (OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp, OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode, OS_FLAGS flags, INT8U wait_type, INT16U timeout)
00951 {
00952     OS_FLAG_NODE  *pnode_next;
00953     INT8U          y;
00954 
00955 
00956     OSTCBCur->OSTCBStat      |= OS_STAT_FLAG;
00957     OSTCBCur->OSTCBPendTO     = FALSE;
00958     OSTCBCur->OSTCBDly        = timeout;              /* Store timeout in task's TCB                   */
00959     OSTCBCur->OSTCBEventPtr   = (OS_EVENT *)0;
00960 #if OS_TASK_DEL_EN > 0
00961     OSTCBCur->OSTCBFlagNode   = pnode;                /* TCB to link to node                           */
00962 #endif
00963     pnode->OSFlagNodeFlags    = flags;                /* Save the flags that we need to wait for       */
00964     pnode->OSFlagNodeWaitType = wait_type;            /* Save the type of wait we are doing            */
00965     pnode->OSFlagNodeTCB      = (void *)OSTCBCur;     /* Link to task's TCB                            */
00966     pnode->OSFlagNodeNext     = pgrp->OSFlagWaitList; /* Add node at beginning of event flag wait list */
00967     pnode->OSFlagNodePrev     = (void *)0;
00968     pnode->OSFlagNodeFlagGrp  = (void *)pgrp;         /* Link to Event Flag Group                      */
00969     pnode_next                = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pgrp->OSFlagWaitList;
00970     if (pnode_next != (void *)0) {                    /* Is this the first NODE to insert?             */
00971         pnode_next->OSFlagNodePrev = pnode;           /* No, link in doubly linked list                */
00972     }
00973     pgrp->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)pnode;
00974                                                       
00975     y            =  OSTCBCur->OSTCBY;                 /* Suspend current task until flag(s) received   */
00976     OSRdyTbl[y] &= ~OSTCBCur->OSTCBBitX;
00977     if (OSRdyTbl[y] == 0x00) {
00978         OSRdyGrp &= ~OSTCBCur->OSTCBBitY;
00979     }
00980 }
00981 
00982 /*$PAGE*/
00983 /*
00984 *********************************************************************************************************
00985 *                                    INITIALIZE THE EVENT FLAG MODULE
00986 *
00987 * Description: This function is called by uC/OS-II to initialize the event flag module.  Your application
00988 *              MUST NOT call this function.  In other words, this function is internal to uC/OS-II.
00989 *
00990 * Arguments  : none
00991 *
00992 * Returns    : none
00993 *
00994 * WARNING    : You MUST NOT call this function from your code.  This is an INTERNAL function to uC/OS-II.
00995 *********************************************************************************************************
00996 */
00997 
00998 void  OS_FlagInit (void)
00999 {
01000 #if OS_MAX_FLAGS == 1
01001     OSFlagFreeList                 = (OS_FLAG_GRP *)&OSFlagTbl[0];  /* Only ONE event flag group!      */
01002     OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_UNUSED;
01003     OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)0;
01004     OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagFlags    = (OS_FLAGS)0;
01005 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
01006     OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';
01007     OSFlagFreeList->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
01008 #endif
01009 #endif
01010 
01011 #if OS_MAX_FLAGS >= 2
01012     INT16U       i;
01013     OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp1;
01014     OS_FLAG_GRP *pgrp2;
01015 
01016 
01017     OS_MemClr((INT8U *)&OSFlagTbl[0], sizeof(OSFlagTbl));           /* Clear the flag group table      */
01018     pgrp1 = &OSFlagTbl[0];
01019     pgrp2 = &OSFlagTbl[1];
01020     for (i = 0; i < (OS_MAX_FLAGS - 1); i++) {                      /* Init. list of free EVENT FLAGS  */
01021         pgrp1->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_UNUSED;
01022         pgrp1->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)pgrp2;
01023 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
01024         pgrp1->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';                                /* Unknown name                    */
01025         pgrp1->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
01026 #endif
01027         pgrp1++;
01028         pgrp2++;
01029     }
01030     pgrp1->OSFlagType     = OS_EVENT_TYPE_UNUSED;
01031     pgrp1->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)0;
01032 #if OS_FLAG_NAME_SIZE > 1
01033     pgrp1->OSFlagName[0]  = '?';                                    /* Unknown name                    */
01034     pgrp1->OSFlagName[1]  = OS_ASCII_NUL;
01035 #endif
01036     OSFlagFreeList        = (OS_FLAG_GRP *)&OSFlagTbl[0];
01037 #endif
01038 }
01039 
01040 /*$PAGE*/
01041 /*
01042 *********************************************************************************************************
01043 *                              MAKE TASK READY-TO-RUN, EVENT(s) OCCURRED
01044 *
01045 * Description: This function is internal to uC/OS-II and is used to make a task ready-to-run because the
01046 *              desired event flag bits have been set.
01047 *
01048 * Arguments  : pnode         is a pointer to a structure which contains data about the task waiting for
01049 *                            event flag bit(s) to be set.
01050 *
01051 *              flags_rdy     contains the bit pattern of the event flags that cause the task to become
01052 *                            ready-to-run.
01053 *
01054 * Returns    : TRUE          If the task has been placed in the ready list and thus needs scheduling
01055 *              FALSE         The task is still not ready to run and thus scheduling is not necessary
01056 *
01057 * Called by  : OSFlagsPost() OS_FLAG.C
01058 *
01059 * Note(s)    : 1) This function assumes that interrupts are disabled.
01060 *              2) This function is INTERNAL to uC/OS-II and your application should not call it.
01061 *********************************************************************************************************
01062 */
01063 
01064 static  BOOLEAN  OS_FlagTaskRdy (OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode, OS_FLAGS flags_rdy)
01065 {
01066     OS_TCB   *ptcb;
01067     BOOLEAN   sched;
01068 
01069 
01070     ptcb                = (OS_TCB *)pnode->OSFlagNodeTCB;  /* Point to TCB of waiting task             */
01071     ptcb->OSTCBDly      = 0;
01072     ptcb->OSTCBFlagsRdy = flags_rdy;
01073     ptcb->OSTCBStat    &= ~OS_STAT_FLAG;
01074     ptcb->OSTCBPendTO   = FALSE;
01075     if (ptcb->OSTCBStat == OS_STAT_RDY) {                  /* Task now ready?                          */
01076         OSRdyGrp               |= ptcb->OSTCBBitY;         /* Put task into ready list                 */
01077         OSRdyTbl[ptcb->OSTCBY] |= ptcb->OSTCBBitX;
01078         sched                   = TRUE;
01079     } else {
01080         sched                   = FALSE;
01081     }
01082     OS_FlagUnlink(pnode);
01083     return (sched);
01084 }
01085 
01086 /*$PAGE*/
01087 /*
01088 *********************************************************************************************************
01089 *                                  UNLINK EVENT FLAG NODE FROM WAITING LIST
01090 *
01091 * Description: This function is internal to uC/OS-II and is used to unlink an event flag node from a
01092 *              list of tasks waiting for the event flag.
01093 *
01094 * Arguments  : pnode         is a pointer to a structure which contains data about the task waiting for
01095 *                            event flag bit(s) to be set.
01096 *
01097 * Returns    : none
01098 *
01099 * Called by  : OS_FlagTaskRdy() OS_FLAG.C
01100 *              OSFlagPend()     OS_FLAG.C
01101 *              OSTaskDel()      OS_TASK.C
01102 *
01103 * Note(s)    : 1) This function assumes that interrupts are disabled.
01104 *              2) This function is INTERNAL to uC/OS-II and your application should not call it.
01105 *********************************************************************************************************
01106 */
01107 
01108 void  OS_FlagUnlink (OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode)
01109 {
01110 #if OS_TASK_DEL_EN > 0
01111     OS_TCB       *ptcb;
01112 #endif
01113     OS_FLAG_GRP  *pgrp;
01114     OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode_prev;
01115     OS_FLAG_NODE *pnode_next;
01116 
01117 
01118     pnode_prev = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pnode->OSFlagNodePrev;
01119     pnode_next = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)pnode->OSFlagNodeNext;
01120     if (pnode_prev == (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0) {                      /* Is it first node in wait list?      */
01121         pgrp                 = (OS_FLAG_GRP *)pnode->OSFlagNodeFlagGrp;
01122         pgrp->OSFlagWaitList = (void *)pnode_next;              /*      Update list for new 1st node   */
01123         if (pnode_next != (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0) {
01124             pnode_next->OSFlagNodePrev = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0;     /*      Link new 1st node PREV to NULL */
01125         }
01126     } else {                                                    /* No,  A node somewhere in the list   */
01127         pnode_prev->OSFlagNodeNext = pnode_next;                /*      Link around the node to unlink */
01128         if (pnode_next != (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0) {                  /*      Was this the LAST node?        */
01129             pnode_next->OSFlagNodePrev = pnode_prev;            /*      No, Link around current node   */
01130         }
01131     }
01132 #if OS_TASK_DEL_EN > 0
01133     ptcb                = (OS_TCB *)pnode->OSFlagNodeTCB;
01134     ptcb->OSTCBFlagNode = (OS_FLAG_NODE *)0;
01135 #endif
01136 }
01137 #endif
